categoryContent.paragraphOne: Keep your mouth shut, and don't volunteer information.
categoryContent.paragraphTwo: Make a simple, concise statement and then stop talking.
categoryContent.paragraphThree: The more you say, the more you’re responsible for.

categoryContent.paragraphOne: No matter how much your workplace pushes 'team building' and 'family culture'.
categoryContent.paragraphTwo: Remember, they're not your friends and it's still a workplace.

categoryContent.paragraphOne: For people starting a new job.
categoryContent.paragraphTwo: If a task typically takes someone ~3.5 hours and you can get it done in 1 hour, don't turn your task in right away - wait about an hour.
categoryContent.paragraphThree: If your manager(s) discover how productive you really are, they will quickly overwork you without proper compensation.

categoryContent.paragraphOne: Always be prepared to leave your employer because they are prepared to leave you.
Know you're about to get fired? Don't throw your resignation in first in one last show of defiance.
categoryContent.paragraphTwo: The meeting where they let you go is your chance to extract a great severance package and positive references.
categoryContent.paragraphThree: Employers want a clean departure - don't make their life easy.

categoryContent.paragraphOne: Put a mirror behind you at the counter or at your desk.
categoryContent.paragraphTwo: This way angry customers who approach you will have to see themselves in the mirror behind you and the chances of them behaving irrationally lowers significantly.
categoryContent.paragraphThree: No one wants to see themselves act like a dickhead.

categoryContent.paragraphOne: Be careful who you vent to at work.
categoryContent.paragraphTwo: Just because they listen, it doesn't mean that they're your friend or have your best interests at heart.

categoryContent.paragraphOne: Keep a separate master resume with all previous work experience.
categoryContent.paragraphTwo: When sending out a resume for application, duplicate the file and remove anything that may be irrelevant to the position.
categoryContent.paragraphThree: You never know when some past experience might become relevant again, and you don’t want to forget about it.

categoryContent.paragraphOne: Take that break.
categoryContent.paragraphTwo: Working around the clock isn't a badge of honor. You're going to burn yourself out.
categoryContent.paragraphThree: You may think you're too busy and you don't have the time for a break, but even 10 minutes makes a big difference. You need to take care of yourself and that includes taking a break.

categoryContent.paragraphOne: If there is anyone at your job you don’t like, always take special care not to take vacation at the same time as them.
categoryContent.paragraphTwo: Having toxic / stressful people gone from the office is like a mini vacation by itself that you would miss out on if you are gone.

categoryContent.paragraphOne: When starting a new job, find out how long your coworkers have been there.
categoryContent.paragraphTwo: If no one has been working there for very long, and it's not a new company, that may be a red flag.

categoryContent.paragraphOne: As a manager, give praise in public and discipline in private.
Always stay muted unless you're currently speaking.
categoryContent.paragraphTwo: No one needs to hear the background noises of every meeting participant.

categoryContent.paragraphOne: Employers put 'entry level' in job titles to trick applicants into accepting less pay.
categoryContent.paragraphTwo: If the 'entry level' job requires you to have significant experience, demand more than starting pay.

categoryContent.paragraphOne: If you need to wait until your boss is in a good mood to ask for something as simple as time off, you're in a toxic work environment and you need to take steps to exit sooner rather than later.
During a job interview, if offered a glass of water, accept it.
categoryContent.paragraphTwo: That way when you get asked a difficult question you can take a sip for some extra seconds before answering.

categoryContent.paragraphOne: Save your resume as a PDF before sending it out.
categoryContent.paragraphTwo: This guarantees the layout, structure, typography to be 100% consistent for all viewers, and no one will have issues opening it.

categoryContent.paragraphOne: If you make a mistake, admit to the mistake, apologize, and explain what steps you'll take to prevent it from happening again in the future.
categoryContent.paragraphTwo: It's very hard for people to yell at you if you've done that.

categoryContent.paragraphOne: Remember, at a job interview, you're also interviewing the company.
categoryContent.paragraphTwo: Ask more questions, don’t settle so quickly because it might not be for you after all.

categoryContent.paragraphOne: Be careful not to let your guard down in conversations with figures of authority when the conversation is informal, friendly, and non-accusatory.
Be loyal to yourself!
categoryContent.paragraphTwo: Be loyal to your own mental, spiritual, financial and physical wellbeing.
categoryContent.paragraphThree: If that stops aligning with your current workplace, it’s time to try and move on.

categoryContent.paragraphOne: Don't have blind loyalty to a corporation you work for.
categoryContent.paragraphTwo: There is nothing wrong with loving your job or the work you do, but understand that corporations don't reward loyalty.

categoryContent.paragraphOne: When your company sends you an 'anonymous' survey, always assume it's not.
If an employer says you have to treat an entry level job as more than just a job to be successful, that's key for you'll be overworked and underpaid.
50% of a job is just being friendly to the right people.
If you’re working in a technical role (IT, engineering, etc.), write everything you do down as if it was a user manual.
categoryContent.paragraphTwo: Ignore those who say it will be used to replace you.
categoryContent.paragraphThree: It is far more likely to be used to show management 'you can give me that promotion, as the next guy is all set'.

categoryContent.paragraphOne: If a supervisor ever asks you to do something that you know violates policy or is morally questionable/shady, ask them to send you the request in an e-mail / written form.
If you get a nice compliment for doing a good job at work via email, file it away into a separate 'compliments' folder.
categoryContent.paragraphTwo: Next performance review you can easily pull up a whole list of items.

categoryContent.paragraphOne: The one skill to learn, develop, and nurture to be successful is negotiation - the ability to reach an agreement, a common ground.
categoryContent.paragraphTwo: Work, social situations, personal life, the skill will serve you everywhere and not get pushed around.
categoryContent.paragraphThree: You get what you negotiate, not always what you deserve.
